story:
50 Little Birds on the Northern Forest Canoe Trail

The Artist

As an educator, musician, craftsman and artist I have spent a lifetime creating things and teaching others to do so.  Over the years I have been consumed with traditional arts including letterpress, luthiery, boatbuilding, bookarts, lettering and painting.

In 2009 I began carving little wooden birds.  The first fifty birds that I produced were used to raise funds for programs at Blue Stone Folk School, a tradtional arts program that I founded with a group of friends.  

I found bird carving to be very satisfying and continued to carve -- long after the series of fifty birds were complete.  Birds have very strong meaning in many people's lives. Through my carvings I am able to explore and communicate what these birds mean to myself and others.

In 2011 I was named an Indiana Artisan for my work as a bird carver.

Before I ever lift a pen to paper or knife to wood and begin to design or carved, I must have a personal experience with my subjects.  My best times are spent in the field, on foot and in a canoe, seeking out opportunities to observe and experience the birds I love.

In June 2014 I am beginning an expedition, with roots all the way back to childhood, to spend six weeks alone paddling a traditional canoe across the Northern Forest Canoe Trail to observe birds, collect experiences and to inform and inspire new work.

Though I plan to travel alone, I have no desire to travel in a vacuum.  A trip like this becomes more meaningful -- more relevant -- when there are folks behind it.  I am seeking a community of supporters.  Folks that have an interest in what I see, experience and produce.

I Need Your Help – Not Your Donations

I expect that much of this trip will be funded through a Lilly Teacher Creativity Fellowship, a program that serves to facilitate opportunities for creative renewal for Indiana teachers.  I was awarded this fellowship on 2004 to study ukulele building and playing in Hawai’i.  I used the knowledge gained from the experience to teach dozens of individuals to build and to play ukuleles.

The Lilly Fellowship is generous, but there are some gaps in the requested funding

The additional funding that I am seeking here will:

·  Provide needed repairs on the truck that will serve as the support vehicle for this trip.

·  Purchase and install a canoe rack on this truck.

·  Purchase a used camera lens to photograph birds at a distance.

·  Obtain a laptop to facilitate blogging and photo management during the trip.

I am not seeking donations. I am seeking funding.  When individuals pledge to support this trip financially they will receive original artwork of the same value.  These are the same pieces that I offer at galleries, shows and online.  In addition to receiving artwork, supporters will become a part of the network of folks that will receive updates, photos and feedback of this adventure.

If this project is partially funded I will continue to seek opportunities to spend time in the field to inspire future artwork.  Funding will go towards these trips and will be reported to supporters.

Continued Support

If you find this trip interesting your support would is appreciated.  Please share my story with other folks who might support it.  Mention is on your social media.  Follow my links and share them.  Offer suggestions and ask questions.  I’d love to know that you are out there.

Thank you!

story:
Project Oasis - Help This Petaluma Artist with his Most Ambitious Project yet!

Being an artist means the world to me and it's how I live my life; my name is Ryan Petersen.

I'm very excited to create, share, and display my most inspiring project yet. This is the largest piece I have ever attempted, a twelve by twenty-four foot painting, that will breathe the importance of harmony, community, and survival.  

Oasis 12' x 24'This image is only a concept that I have constructed so you can have a visual of what I will be painting as my entry for Artprize 2013. 

 

This is a demonstration of the size and magnitude of this finished piece.

 

The Goal for this Project:

This year, I am the only artist from Petaluma, California who will be an Artprize participant. Artprize is located in Grand Rapids, Michigan and is one of the largest art competitions in the world. Although this endeavor takes place far from home, I am very excited to take on my most motivating and challenging painting yet.

Step one- Complete - I have officially registered for Artprize 2013 as an Artist.

Step two- Complete - I have branched out and linked up with the Harris Building, where Oasis will be displayed.

Step three- Funding. This is where I need your help:

To be able to paint and share this piece is a dream of mine. Besides the enormous amounts of energy and time that go into creating a painting at this magnitude, there are the material costs. 

How your Donation will be used:

  • Material and hardware for the wooden panels.
  • Brushes, rollers, paint and sealer.
  • My studio will not be large enough for this size of a piece so, I will need to rent a larger studio to build the panels and paint in.
  • Art photography and promotional materials.
  • Transportation of the artwork from California to Grand Rapids, Michigan.
  • Travel expenses.

The Drive behind this Painting

A neighbor suggested that I read an artist interview about Ran Ortner. This article triggered an awakening in me...realizing the possibility of becoming the artist I was born to be. This is how I first became aware of Artprize. Being the driven person that I am, I registered! My art will be on display at Artprize, September 18th through October 6th, 2013.

 

Why I make art...

My entire life I have been affected and inspired through art. Growing up I was always drawing action figures, cars, and people from my favorite comic books. Little did I know, this would create a huge impact on my future. I received my first airbrush 10 years ago which shifted the direction of my art. It wasn’t until two years ago that I realized it was time for me to stretch out and grow. It was time to get an Art Studio. I started painting constantly and soon found it necessary to build my own panels. The use of wood became important as the foundation for my artwork. I started collaborating with an artist, my good friend, Travis Neditch. We painted back and forth on a single painting, fusing ideas and styles. Ever since that first collaborative piece was created, the momentum has continued to drive my art. I found that through collaboration: whether it is working side-by-side, with other artists, or simply sharing ideas of projects yet to come, creativity is limitless. Painting is one of my greatest passions, not only is it rewarding work it also makes me happy!

 

Examples of Recent Work

The photos below are some of most recent painting to represent the style and feeling of the animals that will be intertwined throughout Oasis.


Elephant 24” x 48”

 

Rhyno 48” x 66”

 

Shoe Bill 30” x 48” 

   

White Lion  20" x 30"                                                   

 

 

Awesome Gifts you will get for Donating:

Besides being greatly appreciative I have different gifts available at various levels.

  • $25 - 4” x 8” Archival ink and paper print of Oasis
  • $50 - 6” x 12” Archival ink and paper print of Oasis
  • $50 - Custom Oasis t-shirt - pick size one: small, med, Large, X-L 
  • $100 - 8” x 16” Archival ink and paper print of Oasis - signed - Limited to 25
  • $250 - 12” x 24” Archival ink and paper print of Oasis - signed and number - Limited to 25
  • $500 - 16” x 32” Archival ink and paper print of Oasis - signed and numbered - plus a custom Oasis t-shirt - Limited to 15
  • $1000 - 24” x 48” Original Oasis print on wood signed and numbered - Limited to 10 - Plus I will hand paint your name in the finished Oasis painting recognizing your efforts as a main supporter.
  • $5000 or more - Besides being my hero you will receive a 36” x 72” Original Oasis print on wood, signed and numbered. Or an original painting on wood - 24” x 48” - You can pick what you would like me to paint for you or leave it up to me. I will contact you personally so we can discuss the context of your painting before I start. Limited to 3 - Plus I will hand paint your name in the finished Oasis painting recognizing your efforts as a main supporter.

 

The Impact

This project is a dream of mine and something that I am very excited about. Your donations and support will help me to complete my goal. I feel that everyone involved in this project is working together, in order to create something amazing. The truth is, this project will be difficult without your help and encouragement. To accomplish this means the world to me, and I truly appreciate your support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you cannot afford to donate, believe me I completely understand! But you can still get involved, especially by helping me spread the love by sharing my project with your community, family and friends. 

The Indiegogo share tools on this site can also help get the word out!

Thank you so much for your support! 

-Ryan

I will contact you personally so we can discuss the context of your painting before I start. Limited to 3 - Plus I will hand paint your name in the finished Oasis painting recognizing your efforts as a main supporter.

To accomplish this means the world to me, and I truly appreciate your support.
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
If you cannot afford to donate, believe me I completely understand! But you can still get involved, especially by helping me spread the love by sharing my project with your community, family and friends. 
The Indiegogo share tools on this site can also help get the word out!
Thank you so much for your support! 
-Ryan

story:
My name is Kameron Ross and I am a student at the Maryland Institute College of Art. I aspire to be a makeup/special effects artist for film or TV when I graduate. I have been applying and designing makeup for over 5 years, mostly unpaid work for family, friends, and campus activities.  

Recently, I entered two of my pieces in a competition sponsored by international makeup brand Illamasqua. Out of hundreds of applicants in my category (nonprofessional makeup artist), me and three other applicants were selected to participate in a live competition at the British Academy of Film and TV Arts in London on Oct 5, 2013 at 11:30am! I will be applying a makeup design of my creation during 90 minutes in front of makeup industry big-leagues. One of the judges is my all time my idol, makeup artist Alex Box! Applying a makeup in front of her is the equivalent of singing for Whitney Houston. This means so much to me in many ways, and I consider this the highest honor I've ever received for my talents. 

Unfortunately, the competition does not sponsor travel/accommodation for its conestants. I will have to front the cost of round airfare, hotel for two nights, and meals for three days. Below is a breakdown of costs. 
Airfare, roundtrip DC to London: 1002.40$
Hotel, Holiday Inn Heathrow, London: 90$/night, 270$ total
Meals for three days: 12$/meal, 108$ total
Through my part-time job, I am able to cover the costs of meals and hotel, but cannot afford the airfare. I am looking for assistance with the cost of airfare, which will be 1000$ roundtrip from DC to London. If any financial assistance can be offered to me, I would be more than grateful.

View the pieces I entered in the contest at kameronkyleross.com.
Find out more about the competition and the prizes at http://www.illamasqua.com/explore/awards/about-the-awards/

story:
A World Without Violence - NONVIO

21 SEPTEMBER, 2013, 3 PM at KING GEORGE SQUARE, BRISBANE, QLD | NONVIO.ORG.AU



H.H. Sri Sri Ravi Shankar's goal is to create social change through non-violence. He asks people to commit an act of non-violence for every violent act they witness. He also shared ways people can reduce stress in their lives, because, according to Sri Sri, stress is one of the leading forces behind violence. 

NONVIO aims to take action by making violence associated with shame in our society. Where aggression and violence are promoted human values are destroyed but we need to promote human values now more than ever.

The NONVIO event promotes the intolerance of non-violence in all facets of our communities. Our education system needs to inherently exhibit teachings revolving around tolerance, awareness and peace rather than greed and self-promotion. Critically today youth and adults alike need to be educated about the violence towards our natural environment and the degradation of mother earth – with the awareness built through marketing endeavours with the help of your contribution, we can make the voice of Non-violence louder than violence itself. 

OUR GOAL IS TO REACH ONE BILLION ACTS OF NON-VIOLENCE

The Australian Launch Event

 The event on 21 SEPTEMBER, 2013, 3 PM at KING GEORGE SQUARE, BRISBANE CBD is our launching pad in Australia to establish a key message to society about how peace actually starts with you. 

The event will kick off at 3 PM with a welcoming ceremony for keynote speakers and the public present with lighting of the lamp to signify the igniting of our collective awareness. There will be a video message from world peace ambassador H.H. Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. Performances by our volunteers followed by exhilarating yoga and meditation techniques to enliven your being from the inside.  

The paradigm shift in this event happens when the crowd present take their pledges of non-violence. This is where the magic happens. 

Do not miss out on such an opportunity. Donate and support this event. 

Come and be a part of a moment where Australian's mindfully make non-violence louder than violence! 

We are grateful for your contribution

The Art of Living Foundation is a purely volunteer based organisation that is non-profit by nature. Our dedicated volunteers contribute their man hours and own resources to have this event to where it is now. Also, all volunteers are encouraging their employers to contribute resources. 

In hosting such a significant event we humbly request your generosity.

We are running short of funds, because we have not been able to raise funds through sponsorship. Your generosity will ensure it is a dynamite event by covering our expenses: 

  • Venue hire
  • Labour
  • Power access
  • Chairs
  • Waste removal
  • Sound system rental
  • First aid kits
  • Drinks and Refreshments for guests 
  • All marketing material - flyers, pledge cards and website
  • Ad hoc expenses 

Make a difference on the day by showing up too! Collective voices resonate loudly to the community, media and our Government.

We are grateful and fold our hands in reverence to you for showing generosity and support for such a pivotal cause. 

Make a difference - Join the Movement 


Follow us Facebook | Tweet your feet #iamNONVIO | Visit us NONVIO.ORG.AU
story_txt:
A World Without Violence - NONVIO

21 SEPTEMBER, 2013, 3 PM at KING GEORGE SQUARE, BRISBANE, QLD | NONVIO.ORG.AU









H.H. Sri Sri Ravi Shankar's goal is to create social change through non-violence. He asks people to commit an act of non-violence for every violent act they witness. He also shared ways people can reduce stress in their lives, because, according to Sri Sri, stress is one of the leading forces behind violence. 
NONVIO aims to take action by making violence associated with shame in our society. Where aggression and violence are promoted human values are destroyed but we need to promote human values now more than ever.


The NONVIO event promotes the intolerance of non-violence in all facets of our
communities. Our education system needs to inherently exhibit teachings revolving around tolerance, awareness and peace rather than greed and
self-promotion. Critically today youth and adults alike need to be educated
about the violence towards our natural environment and the degradation of
mother earth – with the awareness built through marketing endeavours with the help of your contribution, we can make the voice of Non-violence louder than violence itself. 
OUR GOAL IS TO REACH ONE BILLION ACTS OF NON-VIOLENCE

story:
How It Went Down

While on an epic eighty kilometer bike trip exploring the island of Montreal, an unfortunate zipper accident allowed my entire photography gear to burst out of my bag and smash against the cold hearted, and ever so cruel concrete ground...

This includes the crazy ultra wide angle lens that made people uncomfortable when I brought it up too close to their faces, and the petite prime lens that made some of you fortunate folks look like super models. 

You can only imagine the manly roar I cried out right when this happened... the bike ride back was empty, hallow, and very sweaty...

(Photo is from another bike trip I took prior to this one)

 The Bike Route 

 

 

 

Nikon Repair Centre

The Montreal repair centre didn't have enough parts to fix this grand scheme, so they passed it on to Nikon Toronto.

Nikon Toronto is asking $1,300 for the repairs.

So even if it goes over the $700 Goal, please continue to donate as every dollar helps out!

 

 

Taking a Leap of Faith

Donating a couple of dollars my way will be sincerely appreciated, and my already desperate NYC survival budget will salute you (...it will salute you.)

I won't be able to give the appropriate amount of thanks back to wherever you may be, but I can definitely offer some "perks" your way for helping a chingu out.
 
The perks are listed on the right.

 

 

Watch The Throne

You watched this padawan grow and beast out a couple of nice shots with the camera... But are you ready to see him take his game to a whole new level?

 

There are other ways to help me out.

Please share this campaign with your family and friends!

Let them know that I'm a passionate dude stuck in desperate times... and karma will catch up to them. ;)

Check out the videos and photos on the gallery section!

Send me messages of love and support.

-or just gimme a call!

 

 

 

Thank you for reading!

 

Much love,

David

story:
Printing technology historian Bob Oldham (MA History Museum Studies) and hand printing press collector and researcher Patrick Goossens (MA History) have co-authored and will produce a new book about George Clymer’s Columbian hand press for the 200th anniversary of its invention. The book will detail the life of the Columbian’s inventor, describe the developments that led to the Columbian, and report on Bob’s world-wide census of surviving Columbians and some of the information that was derived from the census.

The book is being composed in Baskerville types using Patrick’s computer-driven Monotype composition caster (see a video at http://youtu.be/ht6ihAKI2yQ), and printed on his 1828 George Clymer Columbian press No. 375 (Patrick pulled first proofs on the Columbian Jan. 18 of one of the appendices, see http://www.flickr.com/photos/35903079@N08/12021...), using Zerkall mould-made paper. The edition will be limited to the number subscribed, with a maximum of 100, plus extra copies for the publishers. The printing of the book is planned for March 2014, with release of the book on April 26, 2014, the 200th anniversary of the publication of Clymer’s announcement in the Philadelphia Aurora and General Advertiser of the availability of the Columbian.

Our goal is to raise sufficient funds to pay for travel from Costa Rica to Antwerp, Belgium, and to purchase the paper and illustration printing plates for the edition. The estimated total required is $4000; any additional funding will be used for binding copies of the book. Up to 100 supporters of the project in the amount of at least $100 will receive a copy of the complete book in sheets, ready for the bindery. Supporters of the project in the amount of at least $25 will receive a copy of the sheet comprising one signature of the book and containing the results of the worldwide census of Columbian hand presses.

story:
Quelques mots sur le projets 

Ceux qui connaissaient un peu David savent qu’il trimballait partout avec lui un appareil photo. S’il a eu un peu de mal à se fixer sur une technologie (passant de l’argentique au numérique pour finalement revenir à la pellicule) il a toujours pris énormément de clichés au cours de ses déplacements et de ses voyages. 

Au fur et à mesure des années il a développé un vrai regard et une grande sensibilité plastique. Amassant de nombreuses images et séries, il avait entamé un long travail de sélection avec l’ambition de pouvoir un jour montrer son travail lors d’une exposition et à travers un livre. 

Mais comme souvent, David a pris son temps et n’a malheureusement jamais pu finir ce projet. 

Nous avons donc décidé de le terminer pour lui. 


Le livre

Il est composé de septs séries classées chronologiquement (réunissant une centaine d’images) qui témoignent de son parcours de photographe et aussi un peu de son histoire. Nous avons essayé de respecter au maximum la sélection que David avait entamé et avons mis en page ces photos de la manière qui nous semblait la plus juste, tout en respectant ses orientations graphiques.

D’une manière plus technique 

- Le livre fait 160 pages.

- Il est au format 17 x 24 cm et sera imprimé sur un beau papier mat 120 g.

- Un spécialiste du traitement des images (photograveur) s’occupera de préparer les fichiers pour l’impression. 

Il sera imprimé au minimum à 200 exemplaires, néanmoins cette impression pourra s’étendre si davantage de personnes en pré-commandent.




A quoi servira précisément l’argent récolté ?

- Impression du livre en 200 ex : 3500 €

- Traitement des images par un photograveur : 2000 €

- Tirage d'une vingtaine de photos au format 40 X 60 cm

- Organisation d'une exposition le temps d'un week-end pour le lancement du livre : à cette occasion, les donateurs pourront découvrir les grands formats, récupérer un exemplaire du livre et leur tirage, et aussi boire un verre.

- Les frais d’envoi des exemplaires aux gens qui ne peuvent pas se déplacer à Paris.

L’objectif minimum à atteindre est l’impression des 200 livres, nombre d’exemplaires minimum pour pouvoir imprimer en offset. 

Soit : Impression + Photogravure + Exposition = 6000 €

(  Les tirages parmi une sélection de 15 photos, et en 3 formats disponibles, seront financés directement par chaque contribution. )

N’hésitez pas bien entendu à faire partager cette page aux gens qui souhaiteraient se procurer un exemplaire.




Laurianne Mariette, Maxime Fittes, Clément Deneux, Patric Paleta

story:
Lightening Below Lake a multi-media project inspired by the idea (indeed by obsession with the idea) of tapping into and creating a portal or link with the "Energy" residing in the Sacred Space of The Quiet House and keeping this "Energy" open and flowing throughout the ReHappening and beyond. Lightning Below Lake seeks to share with patrons a tangible experience of Sacred Energy to be communed with meditated upon, carried away and shared with other beings. 

Lightening Below Lake  will be located in The Quiet House (#11 Camp Rockmont Map Legend) and make use of it in it's original capacity as "A place for meditation and ceremony." 

The process will involve an installation composed primarily of stone and wood the two materials used in the building of The Quiet House by it's designer/constructor Alex "Bill" Reed with the help of Mary Gregory. Other natural materials will be used such as native plant blossoms and fibers, deer moss, horn, shell and bone. An assortment of ceramics will be used, symbolic of one quote of many by the mystic Meister Eckhart which Reed copied into his journals from a translation of, Eckhart's book given to him by, Josef Albers. 

Man made materials will be used sparingly. Lighting will be placed inside hollow logs, gourds and large conch shells. Small sculptures and dioramas representational of a "Sacred Mythology of Black Mountain College" will be placed inside hollow tubes of tree bark, hollowed logs and stumps. A projector will be placed inside a hollow stump hiding it from view. A video will be designed especially for the installation. As the evening draws to a close an original poem composed especially for the occasion will be performed. Works by Black Mountain College poets and others will be presented: Jonathan Williams, Rumaker, Creeley, etc. The audience will be invited to participate in sacred call and response and sacred dance ending the performance and closing Lightening Below Lake a multimedia project dedicated to: Alex Reed, Mary Gregory, Theodore, Barbara and Mark Dreier.  

The work will take place organically as a seed feels the warmth of the sun and opens.

story:
Short Summary

Hi!  Amy Braswell here.  I'm the President of the Board of Directors for Abingdon Main Street, a non-profit community revitalization program.  Abingdon is a beautiful historic town in the mountains of SW Virginia.  My organization is coordinating the installation of our town's first public mural on the side of one of our downtown buildings.  The mural brings together all the things that make our town unique:  our history, charm, location, and our love for the arts and outdoor recreation.  The mural is 50% complete and thus far, has been paid for with funds from the Town of Abingdon and grant funds from the Virginia Commission for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Arts and the VA Dept. of Housing and Community Development.  Local businesses and organizations have also sponsored this project.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this campaign is $5,000, although we really need a total of $10,000 to complete the mural.  So, we hope to exceed our Indiegogo goal.  We are offering some cool perks.  Please note that perks will not be sent until the mural is 100% complete.  Help us finish the mural!

The Impact

When you give to this campaign, you are helping to create a magical piece of art that tells the history of Abingdon in such a unique way.  We intend to maintain the mural so that it will be here for many years to come, for your grandchildren and their great grandchildren to enjoy.  The mural is in a public location, free for all to see, ponder and enjoy.  We are still working on some great ideas to use the mural to educate viewers about each flowing pictorial banner in the mural.

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you don't have extra funds to give to this campaign.  That's okay. Share our page with your family and friends, talk about it with your neighbors, get excited and become a vocal ambassador for us!.  If you live in the Abingdon area, become an Abingdon Main Street volunteer -- we have events where we need extra hands and our teams work to make our downtown a fun place to live, work, play, shop, dine...or just hang out.

story:
When loss becomes art and is then transformed into HOPE.


There are two goals in this campaign:

A)   Raising funds to help Henri put on art exhibitions at a few appropriate venues in North America with the goal of raising awareness that the communities affected by the typhoon and earthquake are still hurting.  Many have not seen repairs to their villages at all.  Some of the funds we receive will go towards an exhibit of the artwork co-created with the survivors of the tragedies that will be displayed in the Philippine Embassy in Washington, D.C. Also, Henri will be letting people know how they can best help those in need as he shows his own photos taken of the devastation in December of 2013 and January of 2014, along with the co-created artwork, which together will build a sense of urgency that much help is necessary.  

B)   Offering the pieces of mixed-media art which Henri made together with the victims, of which will greatly help those families who assisted and collaborated with Henri on the art. Together, the cost of the exhibitions expenses, along with the remainder going to the survivors.


Super Typhoon Haiyan left more than 6,300 dead and over 1,000 missing - one of the most powerful storms to ever have hit the islands. This came on top of the destruction caused by the earthquake less than a month before. Tacloban is ruined beyond recognition. And the reconstruction effort is being delayed due to the turmoil.  People are severely struggling with getting just the necessities.  Relief efforts are far behind what the original goals were.

Henri Cainglet is an award winning Filipino artist on a mission to bring direct assistance to those who need it most. Henri is in the devastated communities often, and has spent a great deal of time doing what few others are able to do - listening to, talking with, and getting the victims involved.  All of the photos shown in this campaign were taken by Henri in his travels doing the work he does for as many survivors as he can. Henri lives and works with the most affected victims of these tragedies. Wherever he goes, Henri educates the public with insight into which necessities are the most urgent, the best agencies to allocate contributions to, and by continuously raising awareness that the areas affected cannot be forgotten - too much still needs to be done. From their shattered lives, he teaches the survivors the skills necessary to create - to create art made from the very pieces of strewn debris scattered across what is left of the communities where his neighbors once called home.


About Henri Cainglet


Henri Cainglet is best known for his "found-objects" art composed of paintings, sculptures, and soft pieces. Mr. Cainglet has created Art in Tacloban after Typhoon Haiyan, and in his home town of Valencia, which is one of the towns in Bohol in the aftermath of the earthquake, using  the objects found along the paths of destruction by these two tragedies. His works have been seen in museums from Singapore and Malaysia, to Berlin, Austria, New York and San Francisco. His unique flair is to incorporate an objects’ unrefined roughness, its original state, into award-winning compositions. Cainglet received the 1996 Grand Prize in the National Visual Arts Competition in Manila, 1st prize in Sculpture, and 2nd Prize in the 1999 Hong Kong City of Life Jeepney Design Contest, among others. He is associated with the Kulay-Diwa Gallery of Philippine Contemporary Art in Manila., whose goal is to discover and promote the works of talented, young Filipino Artists.  Henri was honored to speak before the United Nations on February 18th, 2014 in their “Urban Futures . . . South Meets North” event for the “Age of Connectivity: Cities, Magnets of Hope . . . Imagining the Possible” Series which supported the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), HABITAT III Preparatory Process along with the International Council for Caring Communities, Inc. (ICCC).  Your help in his project will go directly to the victims who need it the most.


just last month...

*below are photos taken by Henri


The Outskirts of Tacloban after the typhoon.


and more.

It's hard to know what's going to happen next.

Amazingly, some things survived, and even among total loss, life begins anew. Certain remnants seemingly give blessings and hope of a new life to come.



What's left to use? Henri and these boys collected shattered pieces and slippers "left behind" to create hopeful art pieces as a tribute.

So many families lost everything, and were torn apart.


Working with the Community

    

*See more families Henri has helped with his art in the Gallery 

Artwork Henri has created with those who were in despair before Henri introduced them to artistic expression.These survivors have found renewed hope, thanks to Henri's motivating them to create art which he hopes will raise funds for these very same. These works were in progress at the time the photographs were taken. Now finished (seen in the Gallery). Creating Art has allowed these victims of the tragedies find hope, and to deal with their despair by creating something of value in the wake of tragedy.


Costs

Contributions will cover  the expenses involved in art exhibits and travel expenses. A portion of the money from the sale of the Art is going to the people needing it the most - some of whose faces you can see above and on the following page. A portion of the proceeds we raise from the backers supporting our cause will go to the accredited organizations. Of all charities Henri knows from his neighbors hurting the most, it is the Switzerland International Red Cross who are doing the most with the money donors are contributing.  Henri hopes to have an exhibition at the Philippines Embassy in Washington, D.C.  Along with some of the pieces made along with the victims of the tragedies,  the following art work done by the award-winning artist. These pieces are part of the collectables for this campaign, and will be delivered to contributors donating at the "Pieces of Hope" soon after Henri completes his current tour of exhibitions.


Pieces of Hope

Shown below are some of the original mixed-media compositions which Henri created and co-created with community members recovering from the twin calamities, as seen in some of the photos of this campaign.

           

     

*The 14 pieces (seen in the Gallery) created with help from the community are available to the donors of the $1500 perk, as well as the other 5 main pieces (varying in price).


Campaign Summary

By helping to fund Henri's US art exhibitions, you help raise awareness of the calamities that ravaged the Philippines late last year that took over 6,300 lives and left over 1,000 missing.  You help this Artist to raise funds which help victims - the children, the women, and the men who lost everything - dwellings, clothing, family members and bread-winners.  Henri's work is unique in that the very process of this project gives the victims hope that some good will come out of their struggles, and out of their efforts to produce creatively.  To be sure, this is not just your ordinary cause. Remember that as this nation was straining to recover from the strong earthquake, and was just picking itself up, then came the typhoon - like ashes covering a phoenix, tragedy compiled upon regained strength and pushed all hope aside.  We can give them our support to let them know hope can never be extinguished altogether. 

  • Please see Henri's achievements on the following pages.

  • Henri also hopes to have exhibits at other venues to further bring attention to the plight of the victims of these tragedies and the Artwork Henri has inspired them to create.


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate any kind of help you can give. If you can't make a monetary donation, please help us spread the word about "Pieces of Hope" by using the Indiegogo share tools to send to your friends, family and colleagues. Thank you.
story_txt:
When loss becomes art and is then transformed into HOPE.There are two goals in this campaign: A)   Raising funds to help Henri put on art exhibitions at a few appropriate venues in North America with the goal of raising awareness that the communities affected by the typhoon and earthquake are still hurting.  Many have not seen repairs to their villages at all.  Some of the funds we receive will go towards an exhibit of the artwork co-created with the survivors of the tragedies that will be displayed in the Philippine Embassy in Washington, D.C. Also, Henri will be letting people know how they can best help those in need as he shows his own photos taken of the devastation in December of 2013 and January of 2014, along with the co-created artwork, which together will build a sense of urgency that much help is necessary.  B)   Offering the pieces of mixed-media art which Henri made together with the victims, of which will greatly help those families who assisted and collaborated with Henri on the art. Together, the cost of the exhibitions expenses, along with the remainder going to the survivors.Super Typhoon Haiyan left more than 6,300 dead and over 1,000 missing - one of the most powerful storms to ever have hit the islands. This came on top of the destruction caused by the earthquake less than a month before. Tacloban is ruined beyond recognition. And the reconstruction effort is being delayed due to the turmoil.  People are severely struggling with getting just the necessities.  Relief efforts are far behind what the original goals were. Henri Cainglet is an award winning Filipino artist on a mission to bring direct assistance to those who need it most. Henri is in the devastated communities often, and has spent a great deal of time doing what few others are able to do - listening to, talking with, and getting the victims involved.  All of the photos shown in this campaign were taken by Henri in his travels doing the work he does for as many survivors as he can. Henri lives and works with the most affected victims of these tragedies. Wherever he goes, Henri educates the public with insight into which necessities are the most urgent, the best agencies to allocate contributions to, and by continuously raising awareness that the areas affected cannot be forgotten - too much still needs to be done. From their shattered lives, he teaches the survivors the skills necessary to create - to create art made from the very pieces of strewn debris scattered across what is left of the communities where his neighbors once called home.About Henri CaingletHenri Cainglet is best known for his "found-objects" art composed of paintings, sculptures, and soft pieces. Mr. Cainglet has created Art in Tacloban after Typhoon Haiyan, and in his home town of Valencia, which is one of the towns in Bohol in the aftermath of the earthquake, using  the objects found along the paths of destruction by these two tragedies. His works have been seen in museums from Singapore and Malaysia, to Berlin, Austria, New York and San Francisco. His unique flair is to incorporate an objects’ unrefined roughness, its original state, into award-winning compositions. Cainglet received the 1996 Grand Prize in the National Visual Arts Competition in Manila, 1st prize in Sculpture, and 2nd Prize in the 1999 Hong Kong City of Life Jeepney Design Contest, among others. He is associated with the Kulay-Diwa Gallery of Philippine Contemporary Art in Manila., whose goal is to discover and promote the works of talented, young Filipino Artists.  Henri was honored to speak before the United Nations on February 18th, 2014 in their “Urban Futures . . . South Meets North” event for the “Age of Connectivity: Cities, Magnets of Hope . . . Imagining the Possible” Series which supported the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), HABITAT III Preparatory Process along with the International Council for Caring Communities, Inc. (ICCC).  Your help in his project will go directly to the victims who need it the most.just last month...*below are photos taken by HenriThe Outskirts of Tacloban after the typhoon.and more.It's hard to know what's going to happen next.Amazingly, some things survived, and even among total loss, life begins anew. Certain remnants seemingly give blessings and hope of a new life to come.What's left to use? Henri and these boys collected shattered pieces and slippers "left behind" to create hopeful art pieces as a tribute.So many families lost everything, and were torn apart.Working with the Community    *See more families Henri has helped with his art in the Gallery Artwork Henri has created with those who were in despair before Henri introduced them to artistic expression.These survivors have found renewed hope, thanks to Henri's motivating them to create art which he hopes will raise funds for these very same. These works were in progress at the time the photographs were taken. Now finished (seen in the Gallery). Creating Art has allowed these victims of the tragedies find hope, and to deal with their despair by creating something of value in the wake of tragedy.CostsContributions will cover  the expenses involved in art exhibits and travel expenses. A portion of the money from the sale of the Art is going to the people needing it the most - some of whose faces you can see above and on the following page. A portion of the proceeds we raise from the backers supporting our cause will go to the accredited organizations. Of all charities Henri knows from his neighbors hurting the most, it is the Switzerland International Red Cross who are doing the most with the money donors are contributing.  Henri hopes to have an exhibition at the Philippines Embassy in Washington, D.C.  Along with some of the pieces made along with the victims of the tragedies,  the following art work done by the award-winning artist. These pieces are part of the collectables for this campaign, and will be delivered to contributors donating at the "Pieces of Hope" soon after Henri completes his current tour of exhibitions.Pieces of HopeShown below are some of the original mixed-media compositions which Henri created and co-created with community members recovering from the twin calamities, as seen in some of the photos of this campaign.                 *The 14 pieces (seen in the Gallery) created with help from the community are available to the donors of the $1500 perk, as well as the other 5 main pieces (varying in price).Campaign SummaryBy helping to fund Henri's US art exhibitions, you help raise awareness of the calamities that ravaged the Philippines late last year that took over 6,300 lives and left over 1,000 missing.  You help this Artist to raise funds which help victims - the children, the women, and the men who lost everything - dwellings, clothing, family members and bread-winners.  Henri's work is unique in that the very process of this project gives the victims hope that some good will come out of their struggles, and out of their efforts to produce creatively.  To be sure, this is not just your ordinary cause. Remember that as this nation was straining to recover from the strong earthquake, and was just picking itself up, then came the typhoon - like ashes covering a phoenix, tragedy compiled upon regained strength and pushed all hope aside.  We can give them our support to let them know hope can never be extinguished altogether. 
Please see Henri's achievements on the following pages.
Henri also hopes to have exhibits at other venues to further bring attention to the plight of the victims of these tragedies and the Artwork Henri has inspired them to create.
Other Ways You Can HelpWe appreciate any kind of help you can give. If you can't make a monetary donation, please help us spread the word about "Pieces of Hope" by using the Indiegogo share tools to send to your friends, family and colleagues. Thank you.

story:
OPERATION MAPLE FREEDOM

The short summary is, Miss Annie (spacedrunk, retrobeefcake) just wants to go to Canada... specifically, Anime North. But being tight on cash, she needs a little help from you guys!

What will this achieve? Annie finally coming to see her friends up in the Great White North who are politely waiting to meet her. (´∀｀)♡


WHAT WE NEED

MAPLE, AND LOTS OF IT.

Well actually, $600 USD. 600 dollars would get Annie a round trip flight! We're looking everywhere for cheap flights and the closest we can come to costs around $500 USD or so. Extra funds above the flight cost will be used to cover the indiegogo fees and hotel room.


WHAT YOU CAN GET

You can donate as much as you like! We will love you for every dollar of it. But if you would like to donate a little extra, the four of us have perks for you to choose from! (Links lead to our art blogs)

$10 will get you a chibi drawing from Smieska!

$20 will get you a sketch/bust drawing from Kirono! (only requests with Matthew/aph canada)

$30 will get you a full-bodied sketch from Christieanne!

$40 will get you a full coloured drawing from Annie herself!

--We have now added a little Kitten Kissing Booth, choose this perk and you will get a special thanks from Christieanne's cat Oliver ;) --

Choose wisely and either send an ask to the respective artist's tumblr or to silkbodice@gmail.com confirming you've paid, which perk you've chosen, and the details of your request. Be sure to include your indiegogo username so we can be certain it's you!

Disclaimer: All campaign rewards, "perks" will be fulfilled when the campaign is funded

If you feel you can't afford it, that's alright! You can reblog on tumblr if you'd like, tweet about it, share it around on facebook, or just let other people know. Hey, it's up to you, I'm not here to tell you how to run your life!...er, blog.

Thank you for reading, thank you for your time!

This is.... Operation Maple Freedom.

story:
What is SuperGame!?

SuperGame! is an interactive art installation designed by Baltimore-based artists Scott Pennington and Adam Franchino.  SuperGame! is a central hexagonal structure and cantilevered canopy structure which is home to five carnival inspired games, and will be featured as a part of "Field Day" on Charles St. for Baltimore's Artscape 2014 from July 18th-20th.

SuperGame! will be free for all attending Artscape to play. Each game will award hand stamps to those who prove themselves worthy on the playfield! Collect them all to become a Supergame! Champion! The games featured will be classic carnival games... with a twist.

Some game examples are:

  • Political Punk Rack- Throw shoes at politicians, with no legal consequences!
  • Black Hole Corn Hole - Send obsolete satellites through a rotating black hole to destroy the possibly peaceful, probably invading aliens.
  • World Destruction Ring Toss - The world is facing it's final moments.  How many puppies can you save?
  • Battleship Duck Pond - Pick a duck, from a battleship!

Early conceptual rendering of Supergame!

We are grateful to have received partial funding from Baltimore Office of Promotion & The Arts which has allowed us to fabricate the base structure and the games.  Our goal through this campaign is to raise funds in order to make SuperGame! truly super. 

With your contribution we will be able to afford additional lighting to keep the games going after dark, audio equipment for our carny barker M.C.s, a rigorously curated SuperGame! music playlist, enhanced sound effects, plus additional details that are essential to Supergame!'s carnival aesthetic. 

Scott and Adam !

Team SuperGame!

Scott Pennington is a Baltimore based artist and woodworker, Artscape 2014 will be the third Artscape that he has been a part of. In 2008 Scott collaborated with Paige Shuttleworth and a wide array of contributors to create The Interstellar Species Survey: A giant spacecraft inhabited by 8 fabulously costumed aliens that performed various tests on festival goers. In 2010 Scott presented Pink and Blue Dilemma: The Foam Incident. In this (ongoing) large-scale interactive installation, performers attempt to manage foam flowing from an industrial structure (as if it were toxic waste) while festival goers frolic and enjoy the foam. Both projects can be seen here: http://www.scottpenningtonart.com/ 

Adam Franchino has shown his artwork at Artscape once before, in 2010 showing his Auduino Ant Farm, a synthesizer that translated ant movement into noise, as part of Betascape.  His first large interactive installation was Locale Unlimited, a collaboration with Jeremy Stern, in which Adam controlled lights shooting through starscapes hand cut in large paper by Jeremy.  

SuperGame! Would not be possible without the network of Baltimore artists who are volunteering their skills and time to help make this large scale project possible. We are fortunate to have such an enthusiastic community of creative people contributing to aspects of SuperGame! such as construction, painting and sewing of game components, sign making, light animations, sound production, game operation during the festival, and of course, an endless supply of moral support. 

Scott and Adam hard at work on the structure for World Destruction Ring Toss!


Adam inside the humble beginnings of the central Supergame! structure


Battleship Duck Pond in progress and awaiting a proper name  

Political Punk Rack Bean bags (Rewards for bean bag perk!)


Other Ways You Can Help!

Please help spread the word! If you know of anyone who loves a good carnival make sure they know about SuperGame!
