story:
Summary

Hello and welcome to the first stages of Love.Always.: The Tour! Those of you who know me know that for the last five years I have been pursuing my poetry career while finishing my undergraduate degree at San Francisco State University. Well, now that I have graduated, I am ready to take these poems on the road! But of course, I need your help to fund this journey. 

If you know me you know that the last five years have been dedicated to absorbing as much poetry as possible, honing my craft and creating spaces for others to do the same.

If you do not know me, feel free to learn more about me by reading my bio below or following me on tumblr (imanicezanne.tumblr.com), Faceboook (facebook.com/imani.cezanne) and twitter (@imanicezanne). Also feel free to email me with any questions (imaniecezanne@gmail.com).

This Tour is my opportunity to tour the country sharing my passion with any and everyone willing to listen. I have waited 5 years for the opportunity to travel the country doing what I love. I am asking you, the people that have loved and supported me as a new poet on the scene to contribute in any way you can to this extremely important step in both my personal and professional lives. By contribuiting to this fund you are not only ensuring a smooth transition from state to state, you are also supporting my growth as an artist and making my work more accessible to the rest of the country.

What you are funding:

  • Transportation 
  • Nourishment (Gotta eat!)
  • Books! Your contribution will allow me to publish my first book entitled What I Learned In College. 
  • Lodging (assuming I can't find a couch in any particular city)
  • Emergencies (if any)

Who Is Imani Cezanne?

Born and raised in San Diego, CA, Imani Cezanne is a passionate poet, workshop facilitator, community organizer and slam coach. In the past four years she has been on four National Poetry Slam teams (San Diego, Oakland and Hollywood), two of which placed in the top six at the National Poetry Slam. She has competed in the Women of the World Poetry Slam, placed third in the Individual World Poetry Youth Slam in Berkeley, CA and released Love. Always., a CD of her most popular work. She was most recently invited to perform on the TV One network’s Verses and Flow, a cable television show dedicated to showcasing performance poets from around the country, all while obtaining a bachelor’s degree from San Francisco State University. 

Imani is also the founding President of S.P.E.A.K. (Spoken Poetry Expressed by All Kinds), San Francisco State University’s first poetry-centered organization. She organized and hosted S.P.E.A.K.’s bi-monthly open mics  which has showcased nationally known artists such as Rudy Francisco, Prentice Powell, Marshall “Soulful" Jones and more. She also facilitates their monthly writing workshops and led SFSU’s first ever poetry slam team to the College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational in 2011. 

This fall she is planning to spread her work around the country on the Love. Always. Tour with a re-released album and a new book of poems entitled “What I Learned In College.”

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have a few dollars to spare? THAT'S OKAY. I appreciate support in all it's forms. You can:

  1. Get the word out about Love. Always.: The Tour and this campaign. Share it with your friends and family so they can support as well!
  2. Follow me on twitter, tumblr, Facebook, and instagram so you can stay informed about this journey! 
  3. If I'm coming to your city please come out and enjoy the show! The more the merrier 

Tour Dates

September

4th-Berkeley Poetry Slam (Berkeley, California)

8th-San Francisco City Slam (San Francisco, CA)

9th-Aerobics (San Jose, CA)

15th-Spokane Poetry Slam (Spokane, WA)

18th- Lionlike Mindstate (Pomonca, CA)

26th- Bakery Poetry Lounge (Los Angeles, CA)

 

October

9th- Mahogany Poetry Series (Sacramento, CA)

10th-New Shit Show (San Francisco, CA)

16th-Train of Thought (San Diego, CA)

17th-Elevated (San Diego)

22nd-Neo-Soul (San Diego)

 

November 

3rd-Mercury Cafe (Denver, Colorado)

4th-Slam Nuba (Denver, Colorado)

5th- Urbana (New York, New York)

8th- Nuyorican Poets Cafe (New York)

11th-14th (Detroit, Michigan)

16-Bull City Slam (Raleigh, NC)

 

December

2nd-Busboys and Poets (Maryland, Virginia)

4th- Bus Boys, 5th & K (D.C.)

10th-Austin Poetry Slam (Austin, TX)

13th-Dallas Poetry Slam (Dallas, TX)

15th- Fortworth Open Mic (Fortworth, TX)

16th-Fortworth Slam (Fortworth TX)

18th-Killeen Slam (Killeen, TX)

19th- Upstage (Charlotte, NC)

story:
Short Summary

Hello there,

  We are Gabe Moses, JAWS, Shyla Hardwick, Stephanie Amorey and Hillary Kobernick.  We have written, performed and finally slammed (competed) ourselves to the honor of representing ATL, GA at the Boston Nationals as part of the Art Amok! Team.  

  Hillary and Gabe have proudly represented Amok! in the past, but this year the majority of our team is new to the National competition and looking forward to showing our bright faces to Boston. 

 The Art Amok! Poetry Slam Team was founded in 2006, one of Atlanta’s two poetry slam venues. Every year, Art Amok! sends a team of 5 poets to compete at the National Poetry Slam to keep Atlanta on the map of the national spoken word poetry scene. This year, the National Poetry Slam is happening in Boston from August 13-17, 2013.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To get to nationals we need to cover:

Plane tickets 

Hotel

Food (we're not starving artists-just vegetarian, well, some of us at least, don't make us eat McDonald's!)  

When you support us, you'll not only be a superhero for the poetry world, but we'll throw in souveniers, personalized poems, even a massage! 

The Impact

 Your donation will help us continue the proud tradition that is Art Amok! Slam Team.  Like we said before, most of us are new.  Making this team and getting to nationals, for some of us, has been a dream spanning years, come true.  

  While at Nationals, we will have the opportunity to attend workshops and network with poets from all over the nation.  We'll bring these lessons and connections back home with us to enrich the literary lives of our ATL community.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Come out to our open mics, happening every 2nd and 4th Friday at In Tune Music studio.  Also, please LIKE us on Facebook www.facebook.com/artamokslam  you can also follow our blog www.artamokslam.com  and Youtube Channel-- artamokslam

story:
I am Miriam Hughes and have had many career transitions in my life, from selling ice cream to the neighbors' kids (I was supposed to share) in my first decade of life, to drawing architectural schematics for college students (they paid me $5 per drawing to do their homework – I was 11 then) and becoming a medical illustrator, mostly by default.  Someone needed a detailed oriented artist who knew animation – me!  Before computers at that. Add to that sewing, writing, dog training and poop scooping!

However, one subject matter that always captivated me was the egg.  Eggs were magical to me when I was a child and they hold my fascination to this day.  Over the years, as I pursued my serious life, I continually sketched eggs, made soft fabric eggs, explored eggs in history, mythology, cooking and art.  I created brass egg containers and quilted the insides to be fertilized.  My egg art was a poorly guarded secret.  I even created a 14K gold test tube baby, using the lost wax process. This was my artistic interpretation of a fertilized egg in a test tube.

Two years ago, I changed the direction of my life to take a chance and pursue my art seriously.  I have experienced success as a pastel artist, but one day as I was playing around with a new medium, wet felting, the idea of egg containers came to me.  And I started creating and designing what I now call my Feltagge Fleggs, wet felted eggs with legs. These containers are both a work of art and a place to hold your goals, dreams and even secrets.

But I couldn’t stop there.  My paintings and pastels began to take a new direction, and I am now looking at the egg as the idea subject matter to nurture my growth as an artist. 

My show is not the completion of two years worth of work, but rather a milestone in my journey.  This show is the not the end of my exploration with eggs as my focus; it is my commitment to continuing what I hope will be a lifelong passion fulfilled.  I am working with several mediums that I have always loved, and adding new ones as I learn.  

My fundraising campaign is important as the best vehicle to bring my innovative egg creations to the art-appreciating public. I will be documenting the process to share in a series of workshops I will be presenting throughout the year. A gallery is hosting this show in June and the funds will be used to help make this possible.

My Egg Project will be in the feature artist section of the gallery. My eggs would never have been created if not for being around a collaborative group of artists. After working alone for so many years, the sharing the experience with others and inviting input took me in unexpected and exciting directions!  Part of this exhibit includes an “egg hunt” in the gallery, inviting other artists to create a piece of work where viewers will search for and report their findings.  These search ballots will be recorded and at the end of the exhibit I will hold a drawing with one of my Feltagee Fleggs© as the grand prize.

Eggs symbolize for me the hatching and incubating process.  And my “nest” hosts so many others who unknowingly or not, have contributed, mentored, encouraged and delighted me along the way. This show is my thank you them, but also an invitation to others to join me in the process.  Contributing financially is one way for now, but my goal is to continue to create and encourage collaborations after the exhibit.  I love the idea of helping others to hatch their ideas, to respect their incubation periods and to grow some feathers and fly.  My show at its most basic level is to exhibit my work, but at its dream level it is to help others see where they can reach to in their own creativity.  I strive to be part of the process that encourages others.

The contributions will allow professional filming of the show to be presented to public libraries, area schools and senior centers as a way of engaging the community's awareness of creativity being available to all. The film will include the Quarterly 30-Day Creativity Challenges I offer at the Art MoB gallery in Hendersonville, North Carolina.  Additional funds will be used for the following:

Framing supplies for nice paintings and pastel drawings items ($700)

Printing materials for marketing use, for cards and prints for sale ($500)

Gallery and display hanging items.  These will be donated for other exhibiting artists) to use after The Egg Project. ($600)

Videography and editing  ($700)

 

Now the good part – read about my PERKS!

story:
My name is Grace D. Chin and I make paper flower wreaths, prints, and drawings out of my studio in Lawrence, Kansas. A little over two years ago, I fell in love with a guy from Germany. We’ve spent about a year and half 5,000 miles apart — for those keeping track, that is more distance than both the Proclaimers and Vanessa Carlton combined are willing to walk for love. It’s a real bummer being so far apart, and we’re ready to close the distance.

However, it’s important to me that my ambitions in love don’t interfere with the career I’ve worked hard to build. My plan is to open a similar version of my shop operation in Germany after obtaining a freelance visa. The visa application is a pretty convoluted process that requires not only a lot of paperwork and bureaucratic gymnastics, but also a sizable chunk of money.

Oof.

Here’s where you come in - we can help each other out! 

Maybe you’ve wanted to own a piece of my work for a while, or perhaps one of your loved ones has expressed a desire to have a Grace D. Chin piece in their home - now is your chance. Or maybe you’ve never seen my work before, but the wild world web has brought you here, and you like the art enough to help out a young couple.

To receive the freelance visa, an expatriate must be able to show proof that they have sufficient funds to support themselves and won't become a drain on the German social welfare system. The amount a visa officer looks for varies from officer to officer (also depends on the strength of your supporting documents), but a safe estimate is around 5,000-8,000 Euros. 

My goal is to have $5,000 in addition to moving expenses, but if this Indiegogo campaign exceeds that goal, I’d be over the moon. Moving internationally will take up a great deal of the money I have saved up, and I'd like to go into my Aufenthaltstitels appointment feeling confident about the strength of my application.

What’s great about doing a crowdfunding campaign for my move vs. my regular shop operations is that all of the delivery time is consolidated instead of trying to fulfill a few orders at a time over the course of months. My goal is to leave the states with few to no loose ends - everyone wins. 

The wreath-making kit and tutorial will require a longer wait. These will be sent from Germany, but shipping will remain at about 7 USD. I plan to make more kits, and people selecting this perk will get a discount on future kits to make up for the anticipated wait. 

Before campaign - ordering stickers, prints, and postcards

1/14/20 - Campaign Begins

2/1/20 - Order Enamel pins

2/8/20 - Campaign Ends

2/9/20 - Send surveys for appropriate perks (t-shirts, sticker packs, etc), order stretch goal rewards

2/10/20 - 2/22/20 - Fulfillment Phase 1: postcards, stickers, prints, custom wreaths.

2/24/20 - 2/29/20 - Fulfillment Phase 2: enamel pins

3/1/20 - 3/7/20 - Fulfillment Phase 3: shirts & any remaining perks

3/20/20 - Grace D. Chin online shop closes

4/3/20 - So long, farewell, auf wiedersehen, good byyyye! GDC flies to Deutschland 

5/2020 - Wreath kit fulfillment (if fulfillment of other perks goes well, I will move up the timeline on the kits).

6/2020 - 7/2020 - Visa appointment; if visa is granted (fingers crossed), Grace D. Chin: Deutschland edition will open shop

One of the other requirements for the Freelancer Visa is letters of intent from clients in Germany to hire the artist. Do you know any spaces in the Berlin area who might like host workshops (in English) and/or carry my products? Maybe you know folks in Berlin who have connections to those spaces who can help me out. 

I appreciate any and all efforts to get out the word about this campaign. Your (continued) support means the world to me.

GDC flies to Deutschland 5/2020 - Wreath kit fulfillment (if fulfillment of other perks goes well, I will move up the timeline on the kits).6/2020 - 7/2020 - Visa appointment; if visa is granted (fingers crossed), Grace D. Chin: Deutschland edition will open shopOne of the other requirements for the Freelancer Visa is letters of intent from clients in Germany to hire the artist. Do you know any spaces in the Berlin area who might like host workshops (in English) and/or carry my products? Maybe you know folks in Berlin who have connections to those spaces who can help me out. I appreciate any and all efforts to get out the word about this campaign. Your (continued) support means the world to me.

story:
Our Story

In 1973, Derek Guthrie founded a publication called "The New Art Examiner" that had a 27 year run. On Nov. 1, the anthology, "The Essential New Art Examiner" was published by NIU press and we'd love to fly Derek in from then U.K.


The Impact

Derek still provides powerful commentary about contemporary art, and this is a symbolic gesture that - as always - even without institutional support - he can triumph.


What We Need & What You Get

We need money for airfare and lodging for a few nights. Any contribution of $20 or more will receive video recordings of all documentation during the trip, as we have discussions about art criticism and contemporary art.


Other Ways You Can Help

Check out the book! http://www.amazon.com/Essential-New-Art-Examine...

story:
"Loneliness isn't about being by yourself. That's fine, right and good, desirable in many ways. Loneliness is about finding a landing-place, or not, and knowing that, whatever you do, you can go back there. The opposite of loneliness isn't company, it's return. A place to return."
 - Jeanette Winterson, The Stone Gods

What? 
Landing Places is a Singapore-based, multidisciplinary exhibition happening in conjunction with IndigNation 2012. It features work by 10 queer artists and seeks to document experiences of how our sexualities affect the ways in which we define, create, articulate, question, reject and/or relate to notions of home. The exhibition will comprise drawing, painting, photography, collage, and animation.

Why? 
For many queer individuals, ideas of home are complicated by personal identities running contrary to cultural beliefs: In domestic spaces, many teenagers mute their sexualities for fear of punishment and expulsion. Adult offspring live independently of their parents in order to articulate their own freedoms. Many simply pine for amorphous ideas of “other countries” where their natural instincts are not criminalised. Is home characterised by person, place, culture, belonging? It is space to be cherished, an entity to be built or simply, a cliché? What defines that place to which we “return”?

When?
Landing Places runs from the 16 Aug-6 Sep at Objectifs Gallery, as part of IndigNaton, which traditionally occurs in August. "IndigNation is the LGBT Pride season in Singapore, reaffirming our participation in the intellectual and cultural life of this country, reminding all that we are as much a part of Singapore as anyone else." To find out more about IndigNation, please click here.

Who?
Landing Places is curated by Tania De Rozario and includes work by Jay Bernard (UK), Elisha Lim (Canada), Loo Zihan (Singapore), Ng Yong Heng (Singapore), Valerie Oliveiro (Singapore), Dahlia Osman (Singapore), Jane Porter (Singapore), Gavin Maughfling (UK) and Jason Wee (Singapore).

What Your Contribution Supports:

  • The Initial $300 ---> Utilities for the Space
  • Following  $500 ---> A $50 token material/transport fees for each artist.
  • Following  $200 ---> Printing of Publicity
  • Anything more  ---> I will be giving any excess funds to Indignation/Objectifs, splitting them evenly between the two.

story:
My name is Tim Tate.  I am a sculptor and some of my work is in the form of an infinity mirror.  I have been working as an artist since 1989, and have work in a variety of institutions, such as the Smithsonian American Art Museum.

An amazing show will open  in Venice this May. It is called Glasstress.   It takes place every two years and opens concurrently with the Venice Biennale.  It will include artists like Tony Cragg, Karen Lamonte and Ai Wei Wei. There are only a few artists representing the United States. I am lucky enough to be one of them. This represents one of the highest level shows I have ever achieved within the art world. 

GLASSTRESS is a project by Adriano Berengo dedicated to supporting his mission of marrying contemporary art and glass. Since its debut in 2009 as a collateral event of the Venice Biennale, GLASSTRESS has revived the traditional craft of Murano glassblowing by forging new alliances with internationally renowned artists and designers and has since become an unparalleled platform showcasing ground-breaking new works in glass.


 

They have chosen my piece, The Endless Cycle, for the show. It is my piece about gun violence in America. My goal is to continue to spread awareness on one our countries saddest facets; runaway gun violence.

 

 

The Endless Cycle
36 x 36 x 4
Glass, Aluminum, Poly-Vitro, electronics

For every man shown here, 1000 people died last year because of gun violence in the United States. For every gun shown here, a child dies every day. Only by joining together can we hope to curtail gun violence.

 

It is extremely important to me to attend, but I've been making so much work that I really don't have the money to pay the shipping bill to Venice, let alone attend the opening. I want to represent the USA with all my heart and soul. By sending me, you will be assured that I will represent our country with dignity and enthusiasm.  You will know someone actually in the show, and I will report on every aspect of it. You know I love posting photos of a great event!   :)

 

It will cost $2600 just to ship the work. (International shipping is expensive and challenging. The other $1000 should cover my plane and room. I am frugal beyond belief and have found airfare for 800 and an airbnb for 400. Nothing fancy, but I wont need that. I will be at the show! So I'm trying to raise $4500 total. If anything is over that, I will eat! :)

 

I have several reward categories to choose from, to give you incentive to help me out. Pick any you like!   Also, please share this with anyone who would like to see me be one of the artists representing the United States! I will be forever grateful!

story:
This is a timeless and vibrant tarot deck consisting of 78 tarot cards. Each deck comes with a folded cheat-sheet with glimpses at the meanings of the cards.

 

​what's this all about?

This in an invitation for you to receive a vintage-inspired tarot deck with a modern sci-fi twist. This deck explores themes present in contemporary tarot art such as sci-fi and fantasy, and does it while also keeping both feet firmly on the ground.

If you're a seasoned tarot reader, this is an opportunity to get a fresh viewpoint, and if you're a complete beginner, I've got you covered with a basic cheat-sheet of meanings included with each deck.

 

what you'll receive

The most important benefit offered as a perk within this campaign is the deck itself. It's a 78 card tarot deck printed in full color on 330 g/m2 paper, with rounded corners and no borders. This includes a double sided cheat-sheet with a nudge to the meanings of the cards.

Another option adds a handmade pouch to the tarot deck perk. The pouch is made up of two fabrics, and one of those has been designed and printed to accompany the card designs. The lining is made from another fabric - a randomly selected re-purposed one.

The third option adds a handmade altar / reading cloth to the tarot deck. There are 6 different design variations and the one you receive will be selected at random.

 

 

 

If you pledge under the price of the deck and choose the Digital Artwork perk, you will receive a full color digital image of the Lovers card which you can print in good quality up to 12 x 17 cm size (4.7 x 6.7 in). If you want a specific other card from the Major Arcana please contact me and leave your email and the name of the card that you want to receive and I will be in touch.

 

what I'm asking for & what's to be done

Starting goal: $15'000 to bring this project to life. The money will be used towards printing a first run of the Vibra Tarot deck and shipping it out. This is a starting goal, as I'll be over the moon if this is surpassed and we can print more decks and include stretch goals - yay!

Stretch goal #1: $20'000 in project funds is reached:  the SOLO ALTAR CLOTH perk is unlocked and you can now add a matching altar cloth to your benefits.

Stretch goal #2: $25'000 in project funds is reached: the GILDED EDGES option is unlocked and ALL decks now come with silver gilding of the edges.

What's still to be done in regards to me designing this project is that I've got to design a fabric design for the pouches.

 

risks & challenges

The card designs are finished and ready to print. The only real risk is the risk of missing out on this deck.

There's a great support system of fairy godmothers and godfathers (family and friends) who help with developing the deck whenever input from others is needed. There are around 33 people that have contributed greatly to this project already! MY GRATITUDE TO YOU!

If I don't reach the entire starting goal, I plan to use the money to print the number of decks that have been pledged for and ship them to the contributors.

 

other ways You can help

Love the deck but don't have the cash?

Share this project on your social media or let your tarot friends know specifically.

Leave a comment with some of your love.

The Digital Artwork perk is just $10 so if you want a new background for your phone or a small DIY print, you can give that a go! It's the artwork for the Lovers card by default but if you want a specific other MA card then let me know.

 

the Vibra Tarot timeline

2015 - A couple of sketches of some tarot cards are done - the High Priestess, the Devil and Temperance being some of the first ones. (The finished versions look almost nothing like the first sketches! Phew!)

2016/2017 - Additional Major Arcana card sketches are developed.

2018 - Summer - A screenshot compiling most of the nearly finished Major Arcana cards gets posted on Instagram, and a dear friend urges that the deck be brought into life. The Pip and Court cards are designed.

2018 - Autumn - The final card designs are finished and a printing partner is found. The cheat-sheet design is created.

2018/2019 - Winter - The first test print of the deck is done and the first readings are carried out. The photos for this campaign are taken.

2019 - Vibra Tarot journey unfolds.

 

about the artist

Alise is an artist and tarot reader based in Latvia, Europe. 

She's studied psychology for 6 years, and photography for another couple of years. Her biggest teachers have been plants, animals and fellow humans. She loves the collage medium, and this deck is a testament to that, having been created digitally, collaging many different pieces into one image.

 

- thank you for taking the time to explore this project -

- www.magicwoman.lv -

- more here -

story:
Creativity is a revolutionary act.  Creativity is a meditative practice.  Creativity is a lot of things, but above all else, it's human, and we want to foster it in our community.  And our community expands far beyond Cincinnati's city limits. You are our community.


Your support will empower Make.Do. to:

  • Finance the purchase of the existing retail business
  • Re-format the retail location
  • Hire programmatic staff to develop and deliver training on and off-site around the city
  • Expand retail opportunities for crafters of color to be featured in the shop
  • Create a local yarn and fabric shop that will foster creativity, community, diversity, and inclusion.

Online conversations around diversity and inclusion have done a lot to move us forward. Now let's give that movement a physical space that we can all see, feel, make, and do!
story_txt:

Your support will empower Make.Do. to:

Finance the purchase of the existing retail business
Re-format the retail location
Hire programmatic staff to develop and deliver training on and off-site around the city
Expand retail opportunities for crafters of color to be featured in the shop
Create a local yarn and fabric shop that will foster creativity, community, diversity, and inclusion.

Online conversations around diversity and inclusion have done a lot to move us forward. Now let's give that movement a physical space that we can all see, feel, make, and do!

story:
Hello!

Thank you so much for your interest in our new shop! It feels like the culmination of many spent working together as a couple & creative team, and we can't wait to share it with you! It all still feels pretty surreal, to be honest :)

We (Ashley & Justin) met in art school & have been together since 2004, through all kinds of personal, artistic, and financial ups & downs. For years, we took turns working  random jobs, giving each other alternating time to move our creative goals forward. Over the years I've sold thousands of small drawings, and Ashley built a handmade business that eventually became a full-time job for both of us. Secret Holiday has been our sole livelihood for five years, and we're thankful every day to be able to work, and laugh, and solve problems together.

We've been dreaming about opening a storefront in Northampton for a long time. When we first moved here in 2007, it was already taking shape - - "someday we're going to do this & it's going to be amazing!" But in reality it started a long time before that. 13 year old Ashley had already decided she wanted to go to art school & own a shop when she grew up - - and for me, mid-90s Northampton was the coolest place I'd ever been. I spent a lot of time here - - seeing bands, buying cds & ill-fitting vintage corduroys, and imagining what kind of shop I might open someday in a place like this...  

Well, here we are! By some crazy combination of luck and determination we're in our thirties and nearing the grand opening of our awesome little shop, Grapefruit! And it's happening in this magical, strange little city that is special to both of us in so many ways. We feel so strongly that we belong here, and that we've created something that people are really going to relate to. We've curated a super weird, beautiful, challenging collection of work to share with you - - All kinds of handmade goods, original art, jewelry, self care, books & zines, pop culture artifacts, fancy chocolate... We think it's a really unique mix of art & culture & social consciousness & beauty & coziness, and it is VERY true to who we are. We sincerely hope that it adds something fun & worthwhile to Western Mass :)

Another really great thing is that our studio will be in the back half of the space, so there will be lots of creative energy right here in the shop & potential for all kinds of workshops & events.

We've got about a month left to make it all come together, and there's an overwhelming (but exciting) amount of stuff to get done. The content is all set - - we've got work from several dozen artists & makers (including our own) in house & ready to go... but everything else is in some state of being unfinished or not yet begun :)

We've got to:

- build a dividing wall

- build & buy displays

- paint exterior & some of interior

- install a window

- design & produce signage

- purchase an iPad/cash register

- finish paying for wholesale orders

- purchase all the little essentials: bags, boxes, labels, wrappings papers, office supplies, plants, & a zillion other little things too boring or weird to list

- probably ten other things we haven't thought of yet!

The largest challenge of getting all this accomplished is that we have to take a LOT of time away from Secret Holiday, which is how we actually pay for everything in our lives. There's no loans, no secret benefactor... just us! So there's very little money coming in while we're working to open Grapefruit. If this project we're undertaking interests or excites you at all, please consider helping us fund everything we've got to get done! We would be eternally grateful, and you could simultaneously be purchasing some awesome stuff! 

Here's what's available:

For $10, you get a Grapefruit button & a thank you note

For $20, you get a cool Grapefruit tote bag + button 

For $40, you get a $50 gift certificate to Grapefruit (A nice discount - - 20%! And it never expires!) PLUS the Grapefruit tote bag + button 

For $50, you get 'The Tiger' screen printed poster +  Grapefruit tote bag + button

For $60, you get 'Lovecraft' screen printed poster + Grapefruit tote bag + button 

For $85, you get a MAKE IT HAPPEN screen printed flag + Grapefruit tote bag + button

For $200, you get everything!

That's about it! Take a look at the listings, let us know if you have any questions, and make sure to come visit once we're open. 

Thank you so much for reading our story, & for your generous contributions to this project. We appreciate your support so much & look forward to sharing our shop with you all.

Love, Justin & Ashley

For $40, you get a $50 gift certificate to Grapefruit (A nice discount - - 20%! And it never expires!) PLUS the Grapefruit tote bag + button 
For $50, you get 'The Tiger' screen printed poster +  Grapefruit tote bag + button
For $60, you get 'Lovecraft' screen printed poster + Grapefruit tote bag + button 
For $85, you get a MAKE IT HAPPEN screen printed flag + Grapefruit tote bag + button
For $200, you get everything!
That's about it! Take a look at the listings, let us know if you have any questions, and make sure to come visit once we're open. 
Thank you so much for reading our story, & for your generous contributions to this project. We appreciate your support so much & look forward to sharing our shop with you all.
Love, Justin & Ashley

story:
Mega Mega and I

Nice to virtually meet you! I'm Kevin Bourque, a visual and audio artist based in L.A. As a musician, sound effects designer, live event producer and Emmy award winning filmmaker, I’m passionate about creating captivating experiences for people. My journey through music and film production have inspired me to bring unique and interesting experiences to the playa and beyond. 

 

Some of my more notable creations are SKIN – a multimedia extravaganza, and Cirque Berzerk – world renowned for our stage show Beneath. I also co-founded the Burning Man camp Red Nose District, which you may recognize from the pedal-powered bumper car race track Pedalbump. And I was one of the founding members of Mutaytor, another grand extravaganza borne of the Playa. 

And now I'm working with Michael Dignum ("Diggs") from Steampunk Saloon to bring Mega Mega to the playa. And this one is gonna be a doozy!

 

Mega Mega is a Burning Man Honorarium project funded by both an honorarium grant and some generous donations…and we ONLY need the last $10,000 to bring Mega Mega to the playa. 100% of funding received from this campaign will go toward building and transporting the Mega Mega art installation. We’re going to put every single dollar raised to good use in bringing something crazy to the playa!

Now, Mega Mega is a SUPER SECRET interactive art installation at Burning Man. We really want to tell you all the details, but that would ruin the SURPRISE…but rest assured, the Mega Mega crew and I are twitterpated and titillated to show you what we're up to...so come take a ride with us in this Magical Funderland!

 

How You Can be Involved 

You'll notice the list of perks on the right. While swag is great, with a donation of $25 or more you’ll become a member of our Mega Mega team and you'll get the skinny on this Top Secret project (not to be shared!… seriously…just don’t…why ruin it for everyone else?).  Of course if you DON’T want to know the surprise, and experience it for the first time on Playa, let us know and we’ll keep our lips zipped. 

If you can’t support us with default world funding, no worries, your enthusiasm and support is just as valuable! Tweet, Facebook, tumblr, Linkedin, and Slack about the Mega Mega IndieGoGo campaign…or you know, actually TALK about Mega Mega with your fellow burners at regionals, pre-burn planning sessions, and not-so-secret gatherings. We’re VERY thankful for any support you can offer during our campaign. 

 

Spreading the word about the Mega Mega IndieGoGo is just as important!

 

Playa Ready

Bringing big art to the playa is no joke! Successfully building and managing this installation requires comprehensive experience and skills. I have first-hand experience with plans going sideways, starting back in 1999 with a huge interactive musical and visual experience called Kaliadome. It blew down...but, with chutzpah, we turned the toppled Kaliadome into an interactive pyramid garden. We rallied and saved it and learned a ton about the unforgiving playa in the process – lessons like that inspired us to develop thorough contingency plans!

On playa, we have to be prepared for dust devils, wind storms, rain, sleet (it HAS happened) and grouchy carnival barkers. Fortunately, we're professional designers and builders on and off the playa and we come prepared.

We're building Mega Mega in a remote location to test everything is working before we erect on playa… and planning every step with contingencies up the wazoo.

Our capable team have decades of experience successfully building and managing large-scale art installations on the playa such as Pedalbump and Steampunk Saloon and producing performances including Cirque Berzerk and Mutaytor. We got this!

 

 

Team Players

Burning Man is what you make of it and I and my awesome team want to make the Mega Mega out of it! Magic happens in the right hands, but don't take my word for it...

My productions over the years have been pretty popular out at Burning Man: Thousands witnessed the birth of Cirque Berzerk in 2005 as we brought a full size big top circus show to Burning Man. The tent was overpacked for every performance and the show went on to perform for months in an even BIGGER tent in downtown Los Angeles to rave reviews. Over 30,000 attendees experienced our show over multiple runs. I created Pedalbump and thousands rode – and crashed – tricked out bumper cars under our bigtop over multiple burns. It was incredible fun! 

I’ve been concocting this particular project, Mega Mega, for YEARS and it’s going to make quite an impression (if you donate $25 or more, you’ll understand what I’m talking about *wink* *wink*).

Burning Man runs on laughter and ridiculous fun and the Mega Mega team of artists and builders are darned sure gonna bring it!

 

Meet the Team!

We have a blast making big art and connecting over our shared enthusiasm to bring Mega Mega to the burn. We'd love to meet you out there but until then, virtually meet the crew! 

  • Kevin Bourque "Ringmaster" – Lead Artist
  • Michael Dignum "Diggs" – Producer
  • "Art" Lazaro – Graphic Design
  • Shak Smart International – Muralist
  • Sarah Gonsalves "Firefly" – Visual Artist
  • Briana Hamilton – Visual Effects
  • Virgil Petrie "BGV" – Lighting Design 
  • Sebastian Huff "The Stuff" – Costume Design
  • Michael Allen – Technical Director
  • Jessica Rue Wilson "Stitch" – Media Manager
  • Myke Weiskopf "Dodge" – Sound Designer
  • Jason Ray Jurica – Construction Foreman
  • Craig Nisker – Quality Assurance 
  • Bryan Sandlin "Folded Laundry" – Carny
  • Charlie Bruchez – Carny
  • Kevin "El Camino" – Carny
  • Taylor Dignum "TBD" – Intern

 

Thank you for reading and supporting our Mega Mega campaign!

We can't wait to see YOU out in the dust!

Virgil Petrie "BGV" – Lighting Design 

Sebastian Huff "The Stuff" – Costume Design

Michael Allen – Technical Director

story:
UPDATE!!! A very generous donor has offered me her frequent flier miles, bringing the cost of the plane ticket down to $200. So now I only need to raise $600 to get Elizabeth's print to her wedding! 

Note: Since I won't need to meet my initial goal of $1,200, the site charges a 9% cut on funds raised. So since I need to raise $550 more flat, I actually need to raise $600 to cover the IndieGoGo fees.


The Printmaking Friendship Story!

In the summer of 2008, after just graduating from college, I made plans to move to Madison, Wisconsin to begin a printmaking internship at Tandem Press. Needing a roommate and friends in this new city, I asked for the phone numbers of my soon-to-be fellow interns, and called Elizabeth Stoutamire in Georgia. I still have a very vivid memory of that phone call; we did not become roommates, but found an instant affinity with each other, working happily together in the print shop over the summer. Printmaking has served as a thread throughout our friendship, and has brought us together for many collaborations. We have made a tradition of visiting each other every few months, always brainstorming a new project, and excitedly making plans for the future.


In May 2009 during the opening for a print exchange and exhibition Elizabeth had organized in Madison, she mentioned something about a guy named Gabriel who had stopped by. She was unusually excited to see the fellow, and breathless when we hung out with him later that night. Something was afoot!


That August Elizabeth visited Chicago and we made our first collaborative print together, a combination of etching and non-toxic photo-etching. In October of 2009 we printed together again, this time producing the screen printed show posters for an exhibition I'd curated. Gabriel drove Elizabeth to Chicago to attend the opening. A year later, in the fall of 2010 we collaborated for a third time on a series of screen prints and an etching, working into a plate with cotton blooms from Elizabeth's Southern childhood and trillium flowers from my youth in Eastern Ohio; flowers that both bloom white and decay to purple, marking the passage of time. By then, Gabriel had proposed to Elizabeth, and she was already talking about screen printing her invitations.


Another year has passed since then, and my life points from Chicago toward London for grad school. Elizabeth and Gabriel are getting married on October 15th, a few weeks after I move, and they've asked me to be in the wedding party. I very much want to return to Wisconsin to help them celebrate, and to give them my wedding gift---a photo-etching of Elizabeth and Gabriel, a hand-made print to commemorate three years of friendship and printmaking---but I can't do it without your help. 


You can see loads more photos of our printmaking friendship here!


Needs & Rewards

Here's my budget:

$800     Plane ticket between Heathrow, London and O'Hare, Chicago

$20       Megabus tickets between Chicago and Madison

$50       Gas to/from Madison to the wedding location (Devil's Head Resort)

$40       Two nights shared room at Devil's Head Resort

$40       Food during 4-5 days of travel

$150     Bridesmaid dress

$50       Printmaking and framing supplies for wedding gift

$50       Shipping costs for rewards

-------

$1,200


UPDATE!!! A very generous donor has offered me her frequent flier miles, bringing the cost of the plane ticket down to $200. So now I only need to raise $600 to get Elizabeth's print to her wedding! 


Note: Since I won't need to meet my initial goal of $1,200, the site charges a 9% cut on funds raised. So since I need to raise $550 more flat, I actually need to raise $600 to cover the IndieGoGo fees.




Here are the rewards!


Donate $10: I'll send you a handwritten and absolutely chock-full-o-doodles letter and thank you note from London. [20 available]


Donate $25: I'll send you a copy of my new poetry book, Grow No Moss, and a handwritten, doodled letter from London. [10 available]


Donate $30: You get a limited edition Think In Print CMYK screen print. [4 available]


Donate $40: You get a limited edition Think In Print photopolymer etching. [7 available]


Donate $50: You'll get a copy of Grow No Moss and a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. [15 available]


Donate $75: A limited edition collaborative screen print with cotton blooms and trillium flowers that Elizabeth and I made together, plus a book and a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. Examples here and here, with 5 options to choose from. [7 available]


Donate $150: Your pick of one of the 2 limited edition collaborative etchings that Elizabeth and I made together, plus a book, plus a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. You can see them here and here. [4 available]


Donate $200: Your pick of a lithograph from my website, plus a Grow No Moss book, plus a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. [8 available]


Donate $250: A choice of a 2011 print-collage from my website plus a Grow No Moss book, plus a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. [3 available]




Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help me get this print to Elizabeth's wedding by sharing this with other people, via email, on Facebook, etc. 

Many thanks!

Donate $75: A limited edition collaborative screen print with cotton blooms and trillium flowers that Elizabeth and I made together, plus a book and a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. Examples here and here, with 5 options to choose from. [7 available]

Donate $150: Your pick of one of the 2 limited edition collaborative etchings that Elizabeth and I made together, plus a book, plus a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. You can see them here and here. [4 available]

Donate $200: Your pick of a lithograph from my website, plus a Grow No Moss book, plus a handmade postcard-a-month, for 9 months, from London. [8 available]

Many thanks!

story:
The Sketch

Hi! I'm Geline Surio. My husband, Jodwin, and I co-lead the Teen Ministry with Jim and Donna Fenton at the City of Angeles International Christian Church. One of our teens has been accepted to IGNITE, a spiritual training program with the aim of instructing and unifying teen Christian disciples who aspire to be church ministry leaders.

Tajai, a sophomore from El Segundo High School, is a smart, beauitful, passionate, talented lady. She has been raising funds to pay for the program but she still needs $775 more! 

The Artist & Your Art

In exchange for your generous donation, Tajai will make for you a one-of-a-kind artwork. It can be of anything you like! It could even be your own portrait! Just email us the picture or the description of what you want, and we'll send it to you! You can see below some of her unique pieces. 

The Masterpiece

With your help, Tajai will be able to register and pay for IGNITE. There, she'll be trained by ministry leaders from around the world. She'll build friendship with fellow teenagers around the US who have the same aspirations. Please donate as much money as you can so that this 15-year-old-teen can be an excellent "example for the believers in speech, in conduct, in love, in faith, and in purity (1 Timothy 4:12)." 

 

TAJAI'S ART PIECES:

~ Portrait of Tajai's youngest brother, Roman. ~

~ K! ~

 

~ Dream Catcher ~

 

~ A Bleeding Heart ~

~ Hibiscus ~

~ Symbols ~

~ "Beyond" ~

story:
Mission Statement:

We are a group of artists committed to building a bridge between the creative communities of Oakland and Guadalajara.

By developing a network of artists, we aim to cross the divide between Mexico and the USA. Oaklajara will facilitate an ongoing conversation between these creative communities, expanding and enhancing possibilities for individuals on both sides of the border.

Our collective comprises both English and Spanish speakers. By engaging local creators in the collaborative artistic process, we will create a bilingual environment for the cross-pollination of artistic endeavors.

We all see and hear a lot of misleading news about Mexico and the United States. To unite, build, create, and learn together is to break down barriers and forge an understanding of our similarities as humans and as artists.

Declaración de nuestra Misión:

Somos un grupo de artistas comprometidos a la creación de un puente entre las comunidades creativas de Oakland y Guadalajara.

A través del desarrollo de una red de artistas, estudiantes y mentores, nos proponemos cruzar la divición entre las naciones fronterizas de México y EUA que facilitará a las comunidades  creativas a involucrarse en un diálogo, expandiendo y mejorando las posibilidades para individuos en ambas localidades.

Nuestro colectivo se constituye de hablantes tanto de Inglés y Español, y al involucrar a creadores locales en los procesos colaborativos artísticos, crearemos un ambiente bilingüe para la mutua polinización de intentos artísticos.

Todos vemos y escuchamos muchos noticias engañosas acerca de México y de EUA. El unir, construir, crear y aprender juntos es derrumbar barreras y forjar un entendimiento de nuestras similitudes como humanos y artistas.

Oaklajara 2013 Plan:

The official dates of Oaklajara this year are November 15th - December 15th. Artists from Oakland, CA will be traveling to Guadalajara, JAL to collaborate with the artistic community there. We want to expand on some of the themes that were explored during last year's project, namely, focusing more on music and on having multiple events in different locations throughout the month. Last year Oaklajara teamed up with members of the art/sound collective S.P.A.Z. from Oakland (http://www.spaz.org), who brought to the table their skills in the realm of sound and their enthusiasm in planning & setting up for events. In years past, Oaklajara has relied on musicians being able to provide their own sound equipment, or on renting equipment, limiting the freedom we had in terms of planning different events. This year, however, members of S.P.A.Z. along with some folks from Guadalajara will be driving a sound system south from Oakland for use throughout the entire Oaklajara project as a semi-permanent and mobile system. With this addition we will be seeking out temporary locations to organize even more social and artistic gatherings, growing our network, and making more projects and interactions possible. We hope that this will better aid us in collaborating with even more artists of all disciplines, allowing us the ability to take the party on the road and to host workshops throughout the month.

This year, in contrast to previous years where we have had just one night to showcase the art and music that has come together during the project, we want to have two main events in Guadalajara. One night will feature bands from Oakland and Guadalajara, and the other night will feature DJs and other electronic sound pioneers from both areas. Both events will include artwork and installations that we have created over the month of collaboration. We are also in communication with people in San Pancho and the San Pancho Art Collective to try and coordinate having a New Year's Eve event there.

The money we raise will be used for purchasing art supplies, renting event space, transporting the mobile creation station, documenting the project, and sharing our creations. The participants from Oakland will be funding their own travel and housing costs.

As always, the workshops and events will be free and open to the public. Oaklajara has been and will continue to be a collective comprised of those who show up and want to participate.

Manifesto:

We exist underground.

We are artists, musicians, vagabonds, poets, blacksmiths, DJs, welders, scavengers, social workers, organizers, sound artists, chefs, butchers, fashionistas, critical thinkers, hustlers, participators, movers and shakers, cultural ambassadors, baristas, seekers of truth, lovers of learning, and human beings. We live in Guadalajara, JAL, and in the Bay Area, CA.

The seeds of Oaklajara were first planted in 2010 when those of us from the Bay Area first traveled to Guadalajara, JAL. While there, we met and were inspired by the creative community there, and decided that we wanted to collaborate with them.

Since then, Oaklajara has manifested itself in many ways. It started as an idea to send art back and forth by mail. tThen, when that seemed insufficient, it turned into a fundraiser event in Oakland where some folks from Guadalajara came up to visit and to help with the creation of art which would come to define Oaklajara's first project: creating an archive of images which would facilitate the acquisition of language skills for both native English and Spanish speakers looking to increase their ability to communicate with each other. The majority of the work that was made for this project was made from salvaged and re-purposed materials and was created in Guadalajara, JAL, in the winter of 2012. The culmination of this project was a gallery opening and free concert featuring three local bands held at the Darjeeling tea house in Guadalajara.

Oaklajara's second major project took place once again in Guadalajara during November and December of 2012. This time, we incorporated more music into the creative process and were able put on and participate in radio shows and to meet and collaborate with other musicians, all the while continuing to host events at which we invited people to come out and to make art out of materials scavenged from the landfill in Guadalajara. The main event took place on a rooftop in the form of a free event where all of the artwork was displayed alongside of an interactive art wall which was continually contributed to by the attendees during the course of the event using materials provided by Oaklajara. the event also featured site-specific installations, photography, screen printing, and live music provided by local bands and DJs from both Oakland and Guadalajara. The event was filmed and the resulting footage was used to create a short documentary about Oaklajara and its participants.

Oaklajara continues to grow and to connect people with one another. Some of us got involved because we heard stories and saw pictures from the events and were inspired to participate. Others of us have met at the events and found kindred spirits - people who don't take everything at face value and who think outside of the parameters prescribed to us by our cultures and our societies. We open up our homes to each other and create a space where like-minded individuals can meet and get to know each other, and we get to have a lot of fun.

Oaklajara will continue to show up, to participate, to support other people's projects, to encourage people to explore themselves and the world around them, to share skills and food, to cultivate an international community of artists, and to create events where people can do things that take them out of their normal routines. Oaklajara's events are always free and have been made possible by a combination of grassroots fundraising, networking, and the sharing of community resources.

Oaklajara is collaborative, resourceful, international, exciting, unintelligible, welcoming, inspiring, eclectic, non-hierarchical, feral, creative, innovative, participatory, curious, and engaged. By being a part of Oaklajara, we are able to embody our shared values of freedom of expression, inclusivity, sustainability, and authenticity.

We are Oaklajara.

El Manifiesto:

Existimos de manera subterránea.

Somos artistas, músicos, vagabundos, poetas, herreros, dj, soldadores, basureros, trabajadores sociales, organizadores, artistas sonoros, cocineros, carniceros, fashionistas, pensadores críticos, personas de poder, partícipes, dinamicos, embajadores culturales, baristas, buscadores de verdad, los amantes del saber, y los seres humanos. Vivimos en Guadalajara, Jal, y en el área de la bahía, CA.

Las semillas de Oaklajara se plantaron por primera vez en 2010, cuando los que estamos en el área de la bahía primero viajamos a Guadalajara, Jal. Una vez allí, nos conocimos y nos inspiramos en la comunidad local de creadores, y decidimos que queríamos colaborar con ellos.

Desde entonces, Oaklajara se ha manifestado de muchas maneras. Comenzó con la idea de enviar el arte de ida y vuelta por correo. entonces, cuando eso parecía insuficiente, se convirtió en un evento para recaudar fondos en Oakland, donde algunas personas de Guadalajara vinieron a visitar y ayudar en la creación de arte que vendría a definir el primer proyecto de Oaklajara: la creación de un archivo de imágenes que facilitaría la adquisición de habilidades lingüísticas en hablantes nativos de ingles y español que buscan aumentar su capacidad para comunicarse con los demás. la mayor parte del trabajo que se hizo para este proyecto se realizó a partir de materiales recuperados y re-utilizados y fue creado en Guadalajara, jal, en el invierno de 2012. la culminación de este proyecto fue una inauguración de una galería y un concierto gratuito con tres bandas locales celebradas en la casa de té de Darjeeling, en Guadalajara.

Segundo gran proyecto de Oaklajara tuvo lugar una vez más en Guadalajara en noviembre y diciembre de 2012. esta vez, incorporamos más música en el proceso creativo, participamos en programas de radio conocimos y colaboramos con otros músicos, a la vez que seguimos organizando eventos en los que invitamos a la gente a salir y hacer arte a partir de los materiales rescatados del vertedero en Guadalajara. El acto central fue un evento gratuito y tuvo lugar en un tejado en donde un muro con ilustraciones iba mutando constantemente a medida de que los asistentes colaboraban e intervenían con sus ideas los procesos creativos previos. El evento también contó con instalaciones site-specific, fotografía, serigrafía, y música en vivo proporcionada por bandas locales y djs de Oakland y Guadalajara. el evento fue filmado y el video resultante se utilizó para crear un corto documental sobre Oaklajara y sus participantes.

Oaklajara sigue creciendo y conecta a las personas entre sí. Algunos de nosotros se involucraron porque escuchamos historias, vimos las imágenes de los acontecimientos y nos inspiramos para participar. otros nos han conocido en los acontecimientos encontrando gente con espiritus en las mismas direcciones que no toman todo al pie de la letra y que piensan fuera de los parámetros establecidos a nosotros por nuestras culturas y nuestras sociedades. Abrimos nuestras casas a los demás y crear un espacio donde personas afines pueden reunirse y llegar a conocer unos a otros, y llegar a tener un montón de diversión.

Oaklajara continuará para crecer, participar, apoyar los proyectos de los demás, para alentar a las personas a explorar por ellos mismos el mundo que les rodea, para compartir habilidades y alimentos, para cultivar una comunidad internacional de artistas, y la creación de eventos en los que la gente puede hacer cosas que los llevan fuera de sus rutinas normales. Los eventos de Oaklajara son siempre gratis, y han sido posibles gracias a una combinación de recaudación de fondos, la creación de redes y el intercambio de recursos de la comunidad.

Oaklajara es de colaborativo, ingenioso, internacional, emocionante, ininteligible, acogedor, estimulante, ecléctico, no jerárquica, salvaje, creativo, innovador, participativo, curioso, y comprometido. por ser parte de Oaklajara, somos capaces de encarnar nuestros valores compartidos de libertad de expresión, la inclusión, la sostenibilidad y autenticidad.

Somos Oaklajara.
story_txt:
Mission
Statement:



	We
are a group of artists committed to building a bridge between the
creative communities of Oakland and Guadalajara. 


	By
developing a network of artists, we aim to cross the divide between
Mexico and the USA. Oaklajara will facilitate an ongoing conversation
between these creative communities, expanding and enhancing
possibilities for individuals on both sides of the border.

	Our
collective comprises both English and Spanish speakers. By engaging
local creators in the collaborative artistic process, we will create
a bilingual environment for the cross-pollination of artistic
endeavors.

	We
all see and hear a lot of misleading news about Mexico and the United
States. To unite, build, create, and learn together is to break down
barriers and forge an understanding of our similarities as humans and
as artists.



Declaración
de nuestra Misión:



	Somos
un grupo de artistas comprometidos a la creación de un puente entre
las comunidades creativas de Oakland y Guadalajara.

	A
través del desarrollo de una red de artistas, estudiantes y
mentores, nos proponemos cruzar la divición entre las naciones
fronterizas de México y EUA que facilitará a las comunidades
 creativas a involucrarse en un diálogo, expandiendo y
mejorando las posibilidades para individuos en ambas localidades.

	Nuestro
colectivo se constituye de hablantes tanto de Inglés y Español, y
al involucrar a creadores locales en los procesos colaborativos
artísticos, crearemos un ambiente bilingüe para la mutua
polinización de intentos artísticos.

	Todos
vemos y escuchamos muchos noticias engañosas acerca de México y de
EUA. El unir, construir, crear y aprender juntos es derrumbar
barreras y forjar un entendimiento de nuestras similitudes como
humanos y artistas.

Oaklajara
2013 Plan:


 
 The official dates of Oaklajara this year are November 15th - December 15th. Artists from Oakland, CA will be traveling to Guadalajara, JAL to collaborate with the artistic community there. We want to expand on some of the themes that were explored during last year's project, namely, focusing more on music and on having multiple events in different locations throughout the month. Last year Oaklajara teamed up with members of the art/sound collective S.P.A.Z. from Oakland (http://www.spaz.org), who brought to the table their skills in the realm of sound and their enthusiasm in planning & setting up for events. In years past, Oaklajara has relied on musicians being able to provide their own sound equipment, or on renting equipment, limiting the freedom we had in terms of planning different events. This year, however, members of S.P.A.Z. along with some folks from Guadalajara will be driving a sound system south from Oakland for use throughout the entire Oaklajara project as a semi-permanent and mobile system. With this addition we will be seeking out temporary locations to organize even more social and artistic gatherings, growing our network, and making more projects and interactions possible. We hope that this will better aid us in collaborating with even more artists of all disciplines, allowing us the ability to take the party on the road and to host workshops throughout the month.
This year, in contrast to previous years where we have had just one night to showcase the art and music that has come together during the project, we want to have two main events in Guadalajara. One night will feature bands from Oakland and Guadalajara, and the other night will feature DJs and other electronic sound pioneers from both areas. Both events will include artwork and installations that we have created over the month of collaboration. We are also in communication with people in San Pancho and the San Pancho Art Collective to try and coordinate having a New Year's Eve event there.
The money we raise will be used for purchasing art supplies, renting event space, transporting the mobile creation station, documenting the project, and sharing our creations. The participants from Oakland will be funding their own travel and housing costs.
As always, the workshops and events will be free and open to the public. Oaklajara has been and will continue to be a collective comprised of those who show up and want to participate.


Manifesto:

We exist underground.


We
are artists, musicians, vagabonds, poets, blacksmiths, DJs, welders,
scavengers, social workers, organizers, sound artists, chefs,
butchers, fashionistas, critical thinkers, hustlers, participators,
movers and shakers, cultural ambassadors, baristas, seekers of truth,
lovers of learning, and human beings. We live in Guadalajara, JAL,
and in the Bay Area, CA.


The
seeds of Oaklajara were first planted in 2010 when those of us from
the Bay Area first traveled to Guadalajara, JAL. While there, we met
and were inspired by the creative community there, and decided that
we wanted to collaborate with them.


Since
then, Oaklajara has manifested itself in many ways. It started as an
idea to send art back and forth by mail. tThen, when that seemed
insufficient, it turned into a fundraiser event in Oakland where some
folks from Guadalajara came up to visit and to help with the creation
of art which would come to define Oaklajara's first project: creating
an archive of images which would facilitate the acquisition of
language skills for both native English and Spanish speakers looking
to increase their ability to communicate with each other. The
majority of the work that was made for this project was made from
salvaged and re-purposed materials and was created in Guadalajara, JAL, in the winter of 2012. The culmination of this project was a
gallery opening and free concert featuring three local bands held at
the Darjeeling tea house in Guadalajara.


Oaklajara's
second major project took place once again in Guadalajara during November and December of 2012. This time, we incorporated more music
into the creative process and were able put on and participate in
radio shows and to meet and collaborate with other musicians, all the
while continuing to host events at which we invited people to come
out and to make art out of materials scavenged from the landfill in Guadalajara. The main event took place on a rooftop in the form of a
free event where all of the artwork was displayed alongside of an
interactive art wall which was continually contributed to by the
attendees during the course of the event using materials provided by Oaklajara. the event also featured site-specific installations,
photography, screen printing, and live music provided by local bands
and DJs from both Oakland and Guadalajara. The event was filmed and
the resulting footage was used to create a short documentary about Oaklajara and its participants.


Oaklajara
continues to grow and to connect people with one another. Some of us
got involved because we heard stories and saw pictures from the
events and were inspired to participate. Others of us have met at the
events and found kindred spirits - people who don't take everything
at face value and who think outside of the parameters prescribed to
us by our cultures and our societies. We open up our homes to each
other and create a space where like-minded individuals can meet and
get to know each other, and we get to have a lot of fun.


Oaklajara
will continue to show up, to participate, to support other people's
projects, to encourage people to explore themselves and the world
around them, to share skills and food, to cultivate an international
community of artists, and to create events where people can do things
that take them out of their normal routines. Oaklajara's events are
always free and have been made possible by a combination of
grassroots fundraising, networking, and the sharing of community
resources. 



Oaklajara
is collaborative, resourceful, international, exciting,
unintelligible, welcoming, inspiring, eclectic, non-hierarchical,
feral, creative, innovative, participatory, curious, and engaged. By
being a part of Oaklajara, we are able to embody our shared values of
freedom of expression, inclusivity, sustainability, and authenticity.


We
are Oaklajara.

story:
8TH AUGUST 2013
Inventor of the laser Dr Charles Townes to be sequenced for Genome Laser art project

http://tmblr.co/ZJM0Csrmxp7t

***** )'( *****

Greetings Burners, Captain Fastly checking in from the fateful Ooligan Airways flight OOL-23. Ooligan Alley are the creators of the legendary rhombic hexecontahedron stage "spikey" at 2 and C in 2011.

Genome Laser is an an audacious Burning Man project in collaboration with Control Tower and friends that spans science, technology and art.

Not that long ago, the act of John Frum landing an aeroplane caused mass hysteria and challenged the belief system of a civilisation. The act of not just recording, but broadcasting in public, for entertainment purposes, the data patterns that not only makes you human, but makes you, you, changes everything.

For the first time in history, at Burning Man 2013, the data from individual human genomes will be broadcast in public via laser beam.

Our mission starts by sequencing the individual human genome. Then, we will encode the 3.2 billion base pairs (ACGT), push the genomic data into custom built pattern generation software that interface with the mammoth 60W laser controller on the Control Tower, and broadcast an incredible light show across the Playa and up into space.

We’re thrilled to be collaborating with the International Arts Megacrew, who built that breathtaking Temple of Transition in 2011, and after a year off are challenging themselves to something completely different with Control Tower, a spectacular interactive landmark that will delight the Playa and act as a beacon for navigation.

Funding Requirements

Building and broadcast the Genome Laser via the Control Tower takes time, but thankfully we have the technical skills and commitment to making this happen on a lower budget. But, we want to go bigger for this project to fulfil it's full potential.

We are seeking to raise $4500 to fund the hardware required to plug into the Control Tower, and also synchronise with a Genome Laser co-located at Ooligan Alley. $3k of the funds raised in this project will be put towards building a co-located laser from our friend Skipp, who provided the lasers to Opulent Temple last year, and a key member of the Control Tower project. So, in other words, by donating to this project you are also helping the Control Tower.

We are building Genome Laser because we can, and because we want to push the boundaries of our imaginations and give something amazing back to the Burning Man community. This is non-profit art project where 100% of the funds raised will be channeled directly into materials - we are paying for our own flights, tickets, food, etc.

Genome Laser is going ahead, it's only a question of how big we can go in terms of co-locational genomic broadcasting. Our core costs include a special laser controller to plug into Control Tower and campaign materials (mission patches, sticker, etc) total $1.5k. Every contribution will be rewarded with a unique and limited edition gifts that have been designed and created with love to send our thanks to all the brilliant people who can help this crazy dream become a reality.

How else you can help?

Even if you cannot make a financial contribution then there are still ways that you can get involved - we're looking for people to help in technical and non-technical roles. Just as the Playa presents a blank canvas for people to construct their wildest dreams, Genome Laser provides a framework for experts in pattern recognition and visualisation to express to unleash on a mind-blowing project. Otherwise you can help by making some noise in your networks, on and off the Playa.

Thanks folks for all the support, and big dusty lasery love to y'all ;)

Fastly )'(

@ahousley

 

IMPORTANT: IF YOU ARE CONSIDERING GETTING YOUR GENOME BROADCASTED, FIRST YOU MUST READ THE BELOW STATEMENT ABOUT CONSENTS AND DISCLAIMERS.

We will endeavour to respect the privacy level that you request for your personal genome data, however we have to work on the assumption that the laser show can be decoded.

So, in order to be sequenced, you will have to sign and send back a consent which states that you waive all your rights to the sequence and understand that it will be made public and will contain information of a personal nature that may reveal disease predisposition, issues with future reproduction, or genes that may affect future generations. For example, insurance companies or others may use the information against you to withhold insurance or charge higher rates.

You will not hold the Genome Laser art project, any of its organisers, or anyone else associated with it, or supplying genome sequencing or materials, responsible for any damages that may occur by the release of genome information. For now and for ever.

If you contribute in return for the "Broadcase Your Genome" perk and then for any reason cannot be sequenced (i.e. such as timing, location, consent), then you may request for up to your contribution minus transaction fee to be refunded, which may take 30 days after the campaign close date.

If you have any questions, please email alex@genomelaser.com. Thank you!
